title: Judgment on Edom
shortSummary: Obadiah prophesies the coming judgment of God upon Edom for their pride and violence against their brother nation, Israel. The chapter highlights God's justice, the consequences of betrayal, and the ultimate restoration and victory of His people.
timeline: c. 586 BC - During or shortly after the Babylonian destruction of Jerusalem

keyCharacters.name: Obadiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who receives and delivers God's vision concerning Edom's judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Edom
keyCharacters.description: The nation descended from Esau, condemned for pride and violence against Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Jacob (Israel)
keyCharacters.description: The brother nation of Edom, representing the people of God who suffered oppression and captivity.

keyCharacters.name: Teman
keyCharacters.description: A prominent city or region in Edom, noted for its mighty men who will be dismayed.

definitions.definition: Nations or peoples who do not worship the true God; often used to describe Gentiles.
A poetic reference to Edom, named after Esau, the brother of Jacob.
A future time when God will execute judgment on the nations and bring salvation to His people.
A location mentioned as a place of exile for the people of Jerusalem.

outline.heading: Introduction and Oracle Against Edom
outline.description: Obadiah introduces the vision from the LORD concerning Edom, condemning their pride and false security in their mountainous strongholds.

outline.heading: Edom’s Complete Defeat Foretold
outline.description: God declares that Edom’s hidden things and allies will be searched out and that their wise men and warriors will be destroyed.

outline.heading: Edom’s Sin Against Israel
outline.description: The prophet details Edom’s violence and betrayal against their brother Jacob during Israel’s time of calamity, highlighting their shameful actions.

outline.heading: The Day of the LORD and Retribution
outline.description: God declares that the judgment Edom inflicted on Israel will return upon their own head, emphasizing divine justice.

outline.heading: Restoration of Israel and Final Judgment on Edom
outline.description: The chapter closes with the promise of deliverance for Mount Zion, the destruction of Edom, and the establishment of God’s kingdom.

application: Guard against pride and self-reliance, remembering that God humbles the proud and exalts the humble.
Do not rejoice over or exploit the misfortunes of others, especially fellow believers; instead, show compassion and support.
Trust in God's justice and timing, knowing that He will vindicate His people and punish wrongdoing.
Remain faithful and hopeful in times of distress, confident that God will restore and bless His people.

keyVerses.text: The pride of thine heart hath deceived thee, thou that dwellest in the clefts of the rock, whose habitation is high; that saith in his heart, Who shall bring me down to the ground?
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the root cause of Edom’s downfall—pride and false security.

keyVerses.text: For thy violence against thy brother Jacob shame shall cover thee, and thou shalt be cut off for ever.
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the seriousness of Edom’s betrayal and the resulting divine judgment.

keyVerses.text: For the day of the LORD is near upon all the heathen: as thou hast done, it shall be done unto thee: thy reward shall return upon thine own head.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches the principle of divine retribution and the certainty of God’s justice.

keyVerses.text: And saviours shall come up on mount Zion to judge the mount of Esau; and the kingdom shall be the LORD'S.
keyVerses.significance: It proclaims the ultimate victory of God’s kingdom and the judgment of His enemies.
